page.title: 02LONELY BRECKLAND
page.content: With so few dwellings and such a small population, employment is either with the Forestry Commission, in nearby towns or on the small farms. A few cattle are grazed on the meadows in the loop of the Little Ouse and there is a small acreage of arable for wheat grass or sugarbeet. In the N.W. corner public access is banned as the M.O.D. use it for Army manoeuvres. The only public roads are 2 miles of the A134, 1.5 miles of minor road (was B1108) and the minor road north from Santon Downham. There is also an ancient trackway. (See Page 3) There is no railway station and no bus-stop even if and when buses or coaches traverse the area.
